'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-08-25 10:34:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/a64962300ce241bb49fb9d9987cbed3b2d397b86', 'message': "When only .pyc left, the extended API can not be used.

Currently, when only .pyc left, all extented apis, such as
resetting status of snapshot, can not be used.

This is because it only load .py files in api/extention.py.
__init__ and anything that's not .py are all skipped.

This change updates the extention api to load .pyc files
when .py files do not exist.

Change-Id: I80a3c29a50dcb3cb6bf3708dfeb2a3c75194065b
Closes-bug: #1616358
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2016-08-26 01:54:25.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/api/extensions.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/f15d9d5eb079ed41165dbe1888476ac96376d796', 'message': "When only .pyc left, the extended API can not be used.

Currently, when only .pyc left, all extented apis, such as
resetting status of snapshot, can not be used.

This is because it only load .py files in api/extention.py.
__init__ and anything that's not .py are all skipped.

This change updates the extention api to load .pyc files
when .py files do not exist.

Change-Id: I80a3c29a50dcb3cb6bf3708dfeb2a3c75194065b
Closes-bug: #1616358
"}]
commit_message:
When only .pyc left, the extended API can not be used.

Currently, when only .pyc left, all extented apis, such as
resetting status of snapshot, can not be used.

This is because it only load .py files in api/extention.py.
__init__ and anything that's not .py are all skipped.

This change updates the extention api to load .pyc files
when .py files do not exist.

Change-Id: I80a3c29a50dcb3cb6bf3708dfeb2a3c75194065b
Closes-bug: #1616358

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/11/356811/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _metrics: ========================= Emitting Software Metrics ========================= Overview ======== Ironic supports emitting software metrics to statds. This allows operators' to graph and understand performance bottlenecks in their system. Prerequisites ============= This guide assumes you have a statsd server setup. For information on using and configuring statsd, please see the `statsd <https://github.com/etsy/statsd>`_ readme and documentation. Configuration ============= Metrics can be emitted from both ironic and ironic-python-agent. By default, neither project will emit metrics. Ironic ^^^^^^ Configuration ############# Ironic services can be configured to emit metrics to statsd. To enable sending metrics, enable the metrics backend.:: [metrics] backend = statsd If a statsd daemon is installed and configured alongside every ironic service, listening on the default UDP port (8125), no further configuration is needed. If you are using a remote statsd server, configure it.:: [metrics_statsd] # Point this at your environments' statsd host statsd_host = 192.0.2.1 statsd_port = 8125 Metrics Emitted ############### Ironic is currently emitting timing metrics for every API method, as well as for most driver methods. The typical environment should expect between 100 and 500 distinct metrics from ironic, depending on how many drivers are in use. .. note:: With the default statsd configuration, each timing metric may create additional metrics due to how it handles timing metrics. For more information, see statds documentation on `metric types <https://github.com/etsy/statsd/blob/master/docs/metric_types.md#timing>`_. Ironic-python-agent ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Configuration ############# Ironic python agent can be configured to emit metrics to statsd as well. In order to simplify configuration of metrics emitting from ironic python agent, the ironic conductor will configure the agent dynamically on lookup. So, first you must enable the metrics backend for the agent.:: [metrics] agent_backend = statsd In order to reliably emit metrics from the ironic-python-agent, you must provide a statsd server that is reachable from both the configure provisioning and cleaning networks. The agent statsd host and port are configured here:: [metrics_statsd] agent_statsd_host = 198.51.100.2 agent_statsd_port = 8125 Metrics Emitted ############### Ironic python agent currently emits timing metrics for every API method. Deployers who use custom HardwareManagers can emit custom metrics for their hardware. For more information on custom HardwareManager, and emitting metrics from them, please see the `ironic-python-agent documentation <http://docs.openstack.org/developer/ironic-python-agent/>`_. Adding new metrics to ironic ============================ If you're a developer, and would like to add additional metrics to ironic, please see the ironic-lib developer documentation for details on how to use the metrics library. ..TODO:: Link to ironic-lib developer documentation once it's publishing.

commit_message:
unwedge the gate

since changing the infra job to call the new bash script location,
the functional tests now have a permission error:
py.error.EACCES: [Permission denied]: mkdir('/opt/stack/new/python-openstackclient/.tox',)

Change-Id: Ibe7057c99feac952d80156fb996d0193e1b0e497

commit_message:
Provide volume size for tempest volume creation

The tempest volume client used to provide a default volume size. This
was changed in I2a0f5841fe82ab003562749a63bc4894225699c5. Tempest tests
now need to provide a size when creating a volume using this client.

Change-Id: Id1a646cfbd11803a796205af8baa0ac783e9ec3a
Closes-bug: #1620613

added_lines: from tempest import configure CONF = config.CONF kwargs['size'] = CONF.volume.volume_size

commit_message:
Define separate inherited_roles_client for inherited roles

os-inherit APIs enables projects to inherit role assignments from either
their owning domain or projects that are higher in the hierarchy.

Currently roles_client has all the os-inherit APIs methods
but for better maintenance and readability, those should be
in separate client.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I2d5a5699bfe85fde6219758f28f381006b21daa0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/59/365859/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Red Hat, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from oslo_serialization import jsonutils as json from tempest.lib.common import rest_client class InheritedRolesClient(rest_client.RestClient): api_version = "v3" def create_inherited_role_on_domains_user( self, domain_id, user_id, role_id): """Assigns a role to a user on projects owned by a domain.""" resp, body = self.put( "OS-INHERIT/domains/%s/users/%s/roles/%s/inherited_to_projects" % (domain_id, user_id, role_id), None) self.expected_success(204, resp.status) return rest_client.ResponseBody(resp, body) def delete_inherited_role_from_user_on_domain( self, domain_id, user_id, role_id): """Revokes an inherited project role from a user on a domain.""" resp, body = self.delete( "OS-INHERIT/domains/%s/users/%s/roles/%s/inherited_to_projects" % (domain_id, user_id, role_id)) self.expected_success(204, resp.status) return rest_client.ResponseBody(resp, body) def list_inherited_project_role_for_user_on_domain( self, domain_id, user_id): """Lists the inherited project roles on a domain for a user.""" resp, body = self.get( "OS-INHERIT/domains/%s/users/%s/roles/inherited_to_projects" % (domain_id, user_id)) self.expected_success(200, resp.status) body = json.loads(body) return rest_client.ResponseBody(resp, body) def check_user_inherited_project_role_on_domain( self, domain_id, user_id, role_id): """Checks whether a user has an inherited project role on a domain.""" commit_message:
Fix resizing in imagebackend.cache()

The Flat and Lvm backends do not create a 'base image' (the file in the
image cache) when creating an ephemeral or swap disk. However, cache()
expects it to exist when checking if a resize is required.

This change ignores the resize check if the backing file doesn't exist.
This happens to be ok, because ephemeral and swap disks are always
created with the correct target size anyway, and therefore never need
to be resized.

Closes-Bug: 1608934
Co-Authored-By: Matthew Booth <mbooth@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I46b5658efafe558dd6b28c9910fb8fde830adec0

commit_message:
Add support for configuring the OVS firewall driver

This patch introduces a parameter to allow customizing the Neutron
OpenvSwitch agent's firewall driver configuration.

Closes-Bug: 1618507
Change-Id: I595c392f7a1afe2164bf562224d9eda9b3dfa982

added_lines: NeutronOVSFirewallDriver: default: '' description: | Configure the classname of the firewall driver to use for implementing security groups. Possible values depend on system configuration. Some examples are: noop, openvswitch, iptables_hybrid. The default value of an empty string will result in a default supported configuration. type: string neutron::agents::ml2::ovs::firewall_driver: {get_param: NeutronOVSFirewallDriver}

Implements VNFFG into NFVO

implements blueprint: tacker-vnffg

Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

Please check VNFD for correct Connection " "Point.") class VnffgdCpNoForwardingdException(exceptions.TackerException): message = _("Specified CP %(cp_id)s in VNFD %(vnfd_name)s " "does not have forwarding capability, which is required to be " "included in forwarding path") class VnffgdInUse(exceptions.InUse): message = _('VNFFGD %(vnffgd_id)s is still in use') class VnffgCreateFailed(exceptions.TackerException): message = _('Creating VNFFG based on %(vnffd_id)s failed') class VnffgNotFound(exceptions.NotFound): message = _('Vnffg %(vnffg_id)s could not be found') class VnffgVnfNotFound(exceptions.NotFound): message = _("Specified VNF instance %(vnf_name)s in VNF Mapping could not " "be found") class VnffgDeleteFailed(exceptions.TackerException): message = commit_message:
DHCP: device manager: two new methods - plug and unplug

This enabled decomposed plugins to overwrite methods
from the base class.

An example for this is the simple DVS plugin. Here the plugin
does not require an agent to configure the OVS. This can be
wired directly. An example of this usage is at:

https://review.openstack.org/349248

Closes-bug: #1621043

Change-Id: Iee2bdfc544c2a029df8accaab1a167e42e7b13d4

commit_message:
Remove the dead link in schema migration doc

The schema migration document refers to a another document that
doesn't exist. This patch removes the reference since no appropriate
link could be found.

The doc was also updated to include the copyright.

This fix also resolves a warning in the tox doc build:

/keystone/doc/source/online_schema_migration_examples.rst:23:
WARNING: undefined label: online-migration (if the link has no
caption the label must precede a section header)

Change-Id: I4732651f8c5efd9fa494fd5fba5dad1f782d89a2
Closes-Bug: #1622035

commit_message:
Add Scaling section to User Guide

Scaling container, node section

This section covers current support for container and
node scaling, manual and automatic operation, and
pointers to current discussion.

Partially implements: blueprint user-guide
Change-Id: Iccb9402b664e48deb3a0b020205d3c6d69a96251
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/85/365085/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Containers and nodes -------------------- Scaling containers and nodes refers to increasing or decreasing the available resources. Scaling is a broad topic and involves many dimensions. In the context for Magnum in this guide, we consider the following issues: - Scaling containers and scaling cluster nodes (infrastructure) - Manual and automatic scaling Since this is an active area of development, a complete solution covering all issues does not exist yet, but partial solutions are emerging. Scaling containers involves managing the number of instances of the container by replicating or deleting instances. This can be used to respond to change in the workload being supported by the application; in this case, it is typically driven by certain metric relevant to the application such as response time, etc. Other use cases include rolling upgrade, where a new version of a service can gradually be scaled up while the older version is gradually scaled down. Scaling container is supported at the COE level and is specific to each COE. For Kubernetes, pods are scaled manually by setting the count in the replication controller. Kubernetes version 1.3 and later also supports `autoscaling <http://blog.kubernetes.io/2016/07/autoscaling-in-kubernetes.html>`_. For Swarm, services are scaled manually through the command `scale <https://docs.docker.com/engine/swarm/swarm-tutorial/scale-service/>`_. Automatic scaling for Swarm is not yet available. Mesos manages the resources and does not support scaling directly; instead, this is provided by the frameworks. Scaling the cluster nodes involves managing the number of nodes in the cluster by adding more nodes or removing some nodes. This in turn would allow the cluster to host more or fewer containers. As part of the infrastructure management, Magnum supports manual scaling through the `update`_ lifecycle operation, so you can scale the cluster simply by changing the attribute 'node-count' in the cluster. Adding nodes to a cluster is straightforward: Magnum deploys additional VM's or baremetal servers through the heat templates and invokes the COE-specific mechanism for registering the new nodes to update the available resources in the cluster. Afterward, it is up to the COE's scheduler to begin launching new container instances on the new nodes. Removing nodes from a cluster requires some more care to ensure continuous operation of the containers since the nodes being removed may be actively hosting some containers. Magnum performs a simple heuristic that is specific to the COE to find the best node candidates for removal, as follows: Kubernetes Magnum scans the pods in the name space 'Default' to determine the nodes that are *not* hosting them (empty nodes). If the number of nodes to be removed is equal or less than the number of these empty nodes, these nodes will be removed from the cluster. If the number of nodes to be removed is larger than the number of empty nodes, a warning message will be sent to Magnum log and the empty nodes along with additional nodes will be removed from the cluster. The additional nodes are selected randomly and the pods running on them will be deleted without warning. For this reason, a good practice is to manage the pods through the replication controller so that the deleted pods will be relaunched elsewhere in the cluster. Currently, scaling containers and scaling cluster nodes are handled separately, but in many use cases, there are interaction between the two operations. For instance, scaling up the containers may exhaust the available resources in the cluster, thereby requiring scaling up the cluster nodes as well. Many complex issues are involved in managing this interaction. A presentation at the OpenStack Tokyo Summit 2015 covered some of these issues along with some early proposals, `Exploring Magnum and Senlin integration for autoscaling containers <https://www.openstack.org/summit/tokyo-2015/videos/presentation/exploring-magnum-and-senlin-integration-for-autoscaling-containers>`_. This remains an active area of discussion and research.
deleted_lines: *To be filled in* Include auto scaling

Change-Id: I8dc77408eff79b35845f6b9b5dcea6ed211cc858
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2016-09-08 13:53:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ca0a78d92060465bda8c579621d73b6297e8756e', 'message': "Additional logging for placement API

This helps keep track of placement allocations, and makes some of the
errors pop a lot more. While some of those are expected, as the
placement API exists in an optional state, it is useful to be a bit
more verbose on logging to ensure we're working as expected, and that
we are minimizing some of the exceptions listed here.

Add __repr__ to both AllocationList and UsageList to make building
sensible log messages much simpler.

Change-Id: I8dc77408eff79b35845f6b9b5dcea6ed211cc858
"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2016-09-09 13:04:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9e7cad2678a951b892c5528efc44822e70736a34', 'message': "Additional logging for placement API

The code that does allocations in the placement API is a rather
substantial chunk of complex SQL. Even in the case of 3 simple
resources (VCPU/MEM/DISK) we got it wrong, and were having a heck of a
time figuring out why. As we consider adding more complex resources,
especially ones that come from multiple providers, it's really
important that we have a facility to track, during real allocations,
that the usages change in the ways we expected.

This adds a facility at the debug level which does usage queries for
all the resource providers impacted during an allocation. This is only
done if we are at DEBUG level logging or lower. Besides the request
start debug message, this is currently the only DEBUG logging that
exists for the placement API. So if there are performance concerns,
dialing back to debug = False looses no real information except
this. This is the kind of information we will need to debug and verify
that new allocations of more complex resources are doing the right
thing in a more complex environment.

This could also be done in the clients for the placement API, however,
by doing it there it would be a point in time look at allocations, in
an entirely different HTTP request, so would not be able to actually
track how the allocations adjusted for particular requests. And when
multiple requests are happening simultaneously, would be extremely
hard to decypher.

This also logs some of the exceptions as LOG.exception. While they are
not always fatal or problematic, during this first cycle with the
placement-api being a thing, being more loud about odd behavior is
good. It took a lot of staring at the logs to realize how often we
were erroring in non useful ways that weren't entirely obvious.

Add __repr__ to both AllocationList and UsageList to make building
sensible log messages much simpler.

Change-Id: I8dc77408eff79b35845f6b9b5dcea6ed211cc858

commit_message:
Additional logging for placement API

This logs the allocations when we create or delete them.

This also logs some of the exceptions as LOG.exception. While they are
not always fatal or problematic, during this first cycle with the
placement-api being a thing, being more loud about odd behavior is
good. It took a lot of staring at the logs to realize how often we
were erroring in non useful ways that weren't entirely obvious.

Add __repr__ to both AllocationList and UsageList to make building
sensible log messages much simpler.

Change-Id: I8dc77408eff79b35845f6b9b5dcea6ed211cc858

commit_message:
Add an action and workflow to update a plan

This should be used when the plan files are updated in swift to
ensure that the Mistral environment keeps in sync.

Closes-Bug: #1621462
Change-Id: I35be5ed5062bb26ca31b55d049780a1423c2ce46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/21/367921/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class UpdatePlanAction(base.TripleOAction): """Update a plan Given a container, update the Mistral environment with the same name, parses the capabilities map file and sets the initial plan template and environment files if they have changed since the plan was orginally created. """ def __init__(self): super(UpdatePlanAction, self).__init__() def run(self): swift = self._get_object_client() mistral = self._get_workflow_client() mapobject = swift.get_object(self.container, 'capabilities-map.yml')[1] mapfile = yaml.safe_load(mapobject) mistral_env = mistral.environments.get(self.container) mistral_env.variables.setdefault('root_template', mapfile['root_template']) mistral_env.variables.setdefault('environments', [ {'path': mapfile['root_environment']} ]) mistral.environments.update({ 'name': self.container, 'variables': mistral_env.variables, })

commit_message:
Fix alarms_translator fails to pull data

Cielometer driver didn't initialize an update method for alarm tables.

Closes-Bug: #1620247
Change-Id: I1adba11df0047d9f5e904e4837b06700d6126797

commit_message:
Use deploy_changes for sets of nodes

The deploy_changes method involves additional nodes into deployment to
perform necessary tasks to keep clustered software in a consistent
state. A direct execution of tasks on a specific set of nodes does not
involve other necessary nodes and it leads to some failures during
deployments.

Change-Id: Ibbdeb40e4287a3170b57c11d88f5aea0afa2b5c7
Closes-Bug: #1619821

commit_message:
Use deploy_changes for sets of nodes

The deploy_changes method involves additional nodes into deployment to
perform necessary tasks to keep clustered software in a consistent
state. A direct execution of tasks on a specific set of nodes does not
involve other necessary nodes and it leads to some failures during
deployments.

Change-Id: Ibbdeb40e4287a3170b57c11d88f5aea0afa2b5c7
Closes-Bug: #1619821

commit_message:
Require pymod2pkg 0.5.4

This basically provides a number of essential bugfixes needed for
the RPM Packaging of OpenStack, which we need for packaging Newton.
As this is only consumed by renderspec it should be fine even with
the version freeze in effect.

Change-Id: Ia447e143f7efc3ea1d5d0672c105298a24a989db

commit_message:
Refactor candidacy checking tools

This is a large change as it does several things

1. Moves to using the gerrit REST API to collecting open reviews (as
   opposed to ssh)
2. Moves the selection of validating commits from scraping git logs to
   the gerrit REST API
3. Uses the new utils.py function for getting the project data
4. Avoids any git checkouts/downloads during the validation process
5. tools/check-new-candidacy still checks all open changes
6. tools/check-ptl-candidacy.py checks a single change, now specified as
   a change ID rather then a file path

Work to be done in follow-up commits

1. Add testing, now that this is more modular we can mock json blobs to
   test code and avoid regressions
2. Add a manual toll to specify a project and community member and check
   that, even if it doesn't match data in an open review
3. Add quality tools such as flake8 / yamllint to keep code/data neat
4. Modify the docs generation to understand that files are now IRC nicks
   and to get the change author as the candidate.

Change-Id: Ibd7fad3eb4d39f1edca624b981fa602d2b4c4d40

commit_message:
fix osc gate: post_test_hook.sh not found

commit I49d54f009021d65c1ae49faf6b3f0a7acdadd7b3 incorrectly
referenced the new location.

the gate is currently broken with the error:
:post_test_hook:L0:   bash -xe /opt/stack/new/python-openstackclient/tests/functional/post_test_hook.sh
bash: /opt/stack/new/python-openstackclient/tests/functional/post_test_hook.sh: No such file or directory

for the actual location [1]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/master/openstackclient/tests/functional/post_test_hook.sh

Change-Id: I3efe71c76409af95a6f48259e4a6dd34857e2ef0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/52/368252/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: bash -xe $BASE/new/python-openstackclient/openstackclient/tests/functional/post_test_hook.sh
deleted_lines: bash -xe $BASE/new/python-openstackclient/tests/functional/post_test_hook.sh

commit_message:
Update tox.ini files from release-tools gold copy

All OpenStack Charms now contain identical tox.ini files,
not to be modified or made unique within each charm repo.

This is to ensure consistency across charm repos in tox
target naming, approach and purpose, also giving the
charm dev and test experience additional consistency.

Also create empty dirs with .keep files where necessary.
Some classic charms have actions and/or lib dirs, and some
do not. In all classic charms, flake will now check those
dirs to ensure lint coverage of existing or future content.

Change-Id: I435049886d9e2e2bb47d4beeb4f4833a65ae72e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-openstack-dashboard refs/changes/70/367670/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Classic charm: ./tox.ini # This file is managed centrally by release-tools and should not be modified # within individual charm repos.whitelist_externals = juju passenv = HOME TERM AMULET_*commands = flake8 {posargs} hooks unit_tests tests actions libexclude = */charmhelpers
deleted_lines: passenv = HOME TERM AMULET_HTTP_PROXY AMULET_OS_VIPcommands = flake8 {posargs} --exclude */charmhelpers hooks unit_tests tests actionsexclude = hooks/charmhelpers

commit_message:
Update tox.ini files from release-tools gold copy

All OpenStack Charms now contain identical tox.ini files,
not to be modified or made unique within each charm repo.

This is to ensure consistency across charm repos in tox
target naming, approach and purpose, also giving the
charm dev and test experience additional consistency.

Also create empty dirs with .keep files where necessary.
Some classic charms have actions and/or lib dirs, and some
do not. In all classic charms, flake will now check those
dirs to ensure lint coverage of existing or future content.

Change-Id: I345e0b5f365bde8b7331a9dab53deb6984ec96cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-mon refs/changes/58/367658/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Classic charm: ./tox.ini # This file is managed centrally by release-tools and should not be modified # within individual charm repos.whitelist_externals = juju passenv = HOME TERM AMULET_*commands = flake8 {posargs} hooks unit_tests tests actions lib[testenv:func27-dfs] # Charm Functional Test # Run all deploy-from-source tests which are +x (may not always pass!) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "dfs-*" --no-destroy exclude = */charmhelpers
deleted_lines: passenv = HOME TERM AMULET_*sitepackages = Falsecommands = flake8 {posargs} actions hooks unit_tests testsexclude = hooks/charmhelpers

commit_message:

All OpenStack Charms now contain identical tox.ini files,
not to be modified or made unique within each charm repo.

commit_message:
add composable services for Contrail

- Config
- Control
- Analytics
- Database
- Webui

For puppet modules see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/348905

Implements: blueprint contrail-services

Depends-On: I8de63b6e21f8fdf3c2fd13bf5475cce4a85311d6

Change-Id: I7325b4268c4bec5eb7b777ea2a0639d7a8553e93
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/99/346799/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heat_template_version: 2016-04-08 description: > Contrail Webui service deployment using puppet, this YAML file creates the interface between the HOT template and the puppet manifest that actually installs and configures Contrail Webui. parameters: EndpointMap: default: {} description: Mapping of service endpoint -> protocol. Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. type: json outputs: role_data: description: Role Contrail Webui using composable services. value: service_name: contrail-webui config_settings: step_config: | include ::tripleo::profile::contrail::webui

subject: upstream: and options: track-upstream for deb-*
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-08 12:47:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/9cdffc626901a74078b60b30fb5a7c9ab99349ac', 'message': 'WIP: upstream: and track-upstream for deb-*

This is a WIP, please do not merge yet.

The usual workflow for packaging a new upstream release, is to do
"git merge -X theirs <TAG>", with <TAG> being the latest upstream
rleease. With Gerrit, this translates into a merge commit.

In order to be able to do merge commits, the upstream code must be
present in the Gerrit repository, otherwise, this translates into
a serries of patch, which is absolutely not what we want.

Therefore, we need to add this to all deb-* projects:

upstream: <URL>
options:
  - track-upstream

This is what this patch does, with specific upstream URL for each
package.

Change-Id: I6c03f90ffc447203a7b842e5b1840463a9123d1f
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-09-08 15:01:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/8406a6a0fffd238822eb6ba547874b4b15667d1a', 'message': 'upstream: and options: track-upstream for deb-*

The usual workflow for packaging a new upstream release, is to do
"git merge -X theirs <TAG>", with <TAG> being the latest upstream
rleease. With Gerrit, this translates into a merge commit.

In order to be able to do merge commits, the upstream code must be
present in the Gerrit repository, otherwise, this translates into
a serries of patch, which is absolutely not what we want.

Therefore, we need to add this to all deb-* projects:

upstream: <URL>
options:
  - track-upstream

This is what this patch does, with specific upstream URL for each
package.

Change-Id: I6c03f90ffc447203a7b842e5b1840463a9123d1f
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-09-08 15:02:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/a5a4132a81339b4db8a928376c19cce78c7aabd2', 'message': 'upstream: and options: track-upstream for deb-*

The usual workflow for packaging a new upstream release, is to do
"git merge -X theirs <TAG>", with <TAG> being the latest upstream
rleease. With Gerrit, this translates into a merge commit.

In order to be able to do merge commits, the upstream code must be
present in the Gerrit repository, otherwise, this translates into
a serries of patch, which is absolutely not what we want.

Therefore, we need to add this to all deb-* projects:

upstream: <URL>
options:
  - track-upstream

This is what this patch does, with specific upstream URL for each

commit_message:
upstream: and options: track-upstream for deb-*

The usual workflow for packaging a new upstream release, is to do
"git merge -X theirs <TAG>", with <TAG> being the latest upstream
rleease. With Gerrit, this translates into a merge commit.

In order to be able to do merge commits, the upstream code must be
present in the Gerrit repository, otherwise, this translates into
a serries of patch, which is absolutely not what we want.

Therefore, we need to add this to all deb-* projects:

upstream: <URL>
options:
  - track-upstream

This is what this patch does, with specific upstream URL for each
package.

Change-Id: I6c03f90ffc447203a7b842e5b1840463a9123d1f

commit_message:
Update tox.ini files from release-tools gold copy

All OpenStack Charms now contain identical tox.ini files,
not to be modified or made unique within each charm repo.

This is to ensure consistency across charm repos in tox
target naming, approach and purpose, also giving the
charm dev and test experience additional consistency.

Also create empty dirs with .keep files where necessary.
Some classic charms have actions and/or lib dirs, and some
do not. In all classic charms, flake will now check those
dirs to ensure lint coverage of existing or future content.

Change-Id: Icfdf2b2c568ccbb3886278d1825801f4f8cd003c

commit_message:
Update tox.ini files from release-tools gold copy

All OpenStack Charms now contain identical tox.ini files,
not to be modified or made unique within each charm repo.

This is to ensure consistency across charm repos in tox
target naming, approach and purpose, also giving the
charm dev and test experience additional consistency.

Also create empty dirs with .keep files where necessary.
Some classic charms have actions and/or lib dirs, and some
do not. In all classic charms, flake will now check those
dirs to ensure lint coverage of existing or future content.

Change-Id: I8cc9b08f96519f93a06bdc5e273000b9dce51d8d

commit_message:
standardize release note page ordering

In order to support automatically updating the release notes when we
create stable branches, we want the pages to be in a standard order.
This patch updates the order to be reverse chronological, so the most
recent notes appear at the top.

Change-Id: Ib364dcc8eb31275a31c83b68d7914263b183e393
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Upgrading memoize to memoize functions with same kwargs as well

Modifying memoize to take into account kwargs as well.

Change-Id: I06c83b50bb778ee223fd638fbe0465b21157ef19
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/syntribos refs/changes/81/367481/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from hashlib import md5 func_id = md5(str(func.__name__) + str(args) + str(kwargs)).digest() if func_id not in memoized_calls: memoized_calls[func_id] = func(*args, **kwargs) return memoized_calls[func_id]
deleted_lines: if args in memoized_calls: return memoized_calls[args] else: memoized_calls[args] = func(*args, **kwargs) return memoized_calls[args]

Add .gitreview

To support the documented OpenStack gerrit review cycle, add the
.gitreview file that is read by "git review".

Change-Id: If112082777aa4bb04618267242794ff857298230

commit_message:
Fix misnomer in _set_trunk_metadata

Misnomer led to an AttributeError during a metadata setting.
This patch fixes the misnomer and add the missing coverage.

Change-Id: I0abcb4efd893a1c63428717feaaeaa8ffa32c59b
Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/62/368162/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('neutron.agent.common.ovs_lib.OVSBridge.set_db_attribute') def test__set_trunk_metadata_with_None_params(self, mock_f): with mock.patch.object( self.ovsdb_handler, "_get_parent_port", return_value={'name': 'foo', 'external_ids': {}}): self.ovsdb_handler._set_trunk_metadata(None, None, 'foo', []) mock_f.assert_called_once_with( 'Interface', 'foo', 'external_ids', {'bridge_name': 'tbr-foo', 'trunk_id': 'foo', 'subport_ids': '[]'})

commit_message:
Separate remote rsyslog stream from local

This fix separates the remote rsyslog log streams from the local
by binding the remote ruleset to the UDP and TCP input modules.
Additionally new overrides are provided to allow for better customization:
``rsyslog_server_logrotation_window`` defaults to 14 days
``rsyslog_server_ratelimit_interval`` defaults to 0 seconds
``rsyslog_server_ratelimit_burst`` defaults to 10000

The rsyslog.conf is also now using v7+ style configuration settings

This change is a back port of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/367588/

Change-Id: If756e84511ca5e209eaaa7ebe54fdfc9033f42d2
Closes-Bug: #1621559
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/66/368066/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rotate {{ rsyslog_server_logrotation_window }}
deleted_lines: rotate 14

commit_message:
Recover volume status after remove_export

Currently Cinder recover volume's status before remove_export,
which leads that recreated iSCSI targets may be deleted and
attachment fails.

Let's consider the case: A volume is attached to instance A, and then
detached. During detach, Cinder sets volume's status to available and
remove iSCSI targets.
At the exact time the volume is reset to
available but targets are not removed, the volume is attached to
instance 2 and targets are created again. And then former remove_export
removed the recreated targets, and then it leads attachment fail.

This patch is to move remove_export after changing volume's
status.

Change-Id: I914d4badd9b93e9dc8f4ebc4f74314afe95bf855
Closes-Bug: #1616719

commit_message:
Trove workbook for scheduled backups

A Mistral workbook adding a workflow for creating a backup.
This is used by the "trove schedule-create" command to schedule
a backup.

Change-Id: I68d997abf4ec7c32044dd18cf2a70e687c0fed9f
Implements: blueprint schedule-backups

commit_message:
Update tox.ini files from release-tools gold copy

All OpenStack Charms now contain identical tox.ini files,
not to be modified or made unique within each charm repo.

This is to ensure consistency across charm repos in tox
target naming, approach and purpose, also giving the
charm dev and test experience additional consistency.

Also create empty dirs with .keep files where necessary.
Some classic charms have actions and/or lib dirs, and some
do not. In all classic charms, flake will now check those
dirs to ensure lint coverage of existing or future content.

Change-Id: I07aafbb613d13084eb5d88877659f1690f794040
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-openvswitch-odl refs/changes/71/367671/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Classic charm: ./tox.ini # This file is managed centrally by release-tools and should not be modified # within individual charm repos.whitelist_externals = juju passenv = HOME TERM AMULET_*commands = flake8 {posargs} hooks unit_tests tests actions libexclude = */charmhelpers
deleted_lines: # Default to current LTS CHARM_DIR={envdir}passenv = HOME TERM AMULET_*commands = flake8 {posargs} hooks unit_tests testsexclude = hooks/charmhelpers

commit_message:
Compress test execution logs

The volume of logs we collect in CI jobs are extensive. This
patch ensures that the logs collected are compressed to reduce
the space taken in CI systems.

PYTHONUNBUFFERED is also set to ensure that the console log
from the CI jobs is recorded in the exact order of execution.

Change-Id: Ie09211a7761d759c71a5fcbe7062df0196e22b58
Related-Bug: #1620849
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron refs/changes/85/367885/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PYTHONUNBUFFERED=1 [testenv:func_logs] commands = bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync --archive --verbose --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true' bash -c 'find "{toxinidir}/logs/" -type f | sed "p;s|$|.txt|" | xargs -n2 mv' bash -c 'command gzip --best --recursive "{toxinidir}/logs/"' # end of the run. This will not produce a false positive. Any {[testenv:func_logs]commands}# Ignore_errors is set to true so that the logs are collected at the # end of the run. This will not produce a false positive. Any # exception will be mark the run as failed and exit 1 after all of # the commands have been iterated through. ignore_errors = True {[testenv:func_logs]commands}
deleted_lines: # end of the run. This will not produce a failse positive. Any bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true' bash -c 'mkdir -p {toxinidir}/logs' bash -c 'rsync -av --ignore-errors /var/log/ /openstack/log/ {toxinidir}/logs/ || true'

commit_message:
[networking] Describe existing security group behavior

Providing a more complete description of the existing security group
behavior. This should help operators and user better understand what
traffic is permitted by security groups, and should help developers
implementing additional firewall drivers to achieve consistent behavior.

backport: mitaka
Co-Authored-By: Matt Kassawara <mkassawara@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I8cc078161dfbf649f466233230eaf6e4ece0429d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/51/356551/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: permitted to pass through a port. A security group is a container for securitySecurity groups are realized by firewall drivers. Firewall drivers are selected by the operator by the configuration of OpenStack Networking and its plugins, and materialize the underlying firewall configuration rules on each port. The firewall driver is also responsible for generating rules to enforce anti-spoofing and permit instances to acquire IP addresses. Anti-spoofing rules are added each instance port to ensure all traffic received by the network from the instance port has a source MAC and IP addresses which is associated with that instance port. This way, the source address can be relied upon to accurately filter traffic. These source accesses include not just the fixed-addresses of the port, but the allowed-address pairs and the IPv6 link-local address associated with the port MAC address and any additional MAC addresses included in allowed-address pairs. The source MAC and IP address are validated such that only the combinations specified in allowed-address pairs are permitted. For allowed-address pairs specified without a MAC the port's MAC address is used. Fixed-addresses specified on the port are similarly only permitted from the port's MAC address. Finally allowed-address pairs which do not include an IP address are only apply to non-IP traffic. Non-IP traffic is permitted from all MAC addresses including the port's MAC address and MAC addressed included in non-degenerate allowed-address pairs. Finally the firewall driver implements some base rules to permit IP address allocation: * DHCP discovery and request messages sourced from the unspecified IPv4 address (0.0.0.0), are permitted so long as they originate from a valid source MAC address. * ICMPv6 MLD Reports (v1 and v2) and Neighbor Solicitation messages sourced from the unspecified IPv6 address (::), are permitted so long as they originate from a valid source MAC address. These ICMPv6 types are required for an instance to complete Duplicate Address Detection. * DHCP renewal and rebinding messages are permitted from a valid source IP address. * ICMPv6 messages except router advertisements are permitted from a valid source IPv6 address. ICMPv6 is required for IPv6 neighbor discovery. * DHCP and DHCPv6 responses are denied to prevent an instance from acting as a DHCP(v6) server. * ICMPv6 router advertisements are denied to prevent an instance from acting as IPv6 router. These rules are enforced regardless of the user specified security group rules. In addition ARP is permitted since it is actually non-IP traffic. By enforcing these fixed and anti-spoofing rules a verity of malicious first-hop security issues are prevented. The goal being that two instances belonging to different tenants can both use a common shared network safely. Security group, anti-spoofing and fixed rules can be disabled by setting the port_security_enabled port attribute to false. When this is set, the firewall driver does not generate any rules for that port.
deleted_lines: allowed to pass through a port. A security group is a container for security

subject: Automate the STIG documentation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-31 05:01:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security/commit/abb81f121da6c7412042a8bb29e26a3c3757368e', 'message': '[WIP] Migrate to YAML-based docs

With the upcoming changes to rebase onto the RHEL 7 STIG controls,
there needs to be a new solution for documentation that is easier
to manage and filter. This patch sets up a new system of doc
generation that uses YAML frontmatter to provide metadata for
documentation. In addition, the actual STIG XML is used to generate
the base content and this can be easily upgraded over time.

This probably needs to be held out for Ocata, but I wanted to get
some comments on it sooner than that. ;)

Change-Id: I455af1121049f52193e98e2c9cb1ba5d4c292386

documentation. In addition, the actual STIG XML is used to generate
the base content and this can be easily upgraded over time.

commit_message:
Automate the STIG documentation

With the upcoming changes to rebase onto the RHEL 7 STIG controls,
there needs to be a new solution for documentation that is easier
to manage and filter. This patch automates the generation of the STIG
control documentation in the following way:

* A Sphinx extension runs early in the doc build process that writes
  all of the individual STIG control docs as well as ToC pages.
* ToC pages are now sorted by severity, tag, and implementation status.
* A giant listing of controls is easier to navigate now.
* Docs are generated from metadata in the /doc/metadata directory. New
  documentation only needs to be added there. (Will explain this in
  the developer notes in a subsequent patch.)

Implements: blueprint security-rhel7-stig
Change-Id: I455af1121049f52193e98e2c9cb1ba5d4c292386

commit_message:
Update bug tag policy to match actual tag names

Some of the tags in Launchpad are spelled differently. The goal of the
policy is to ease confusion, not increase it - let's update the
document to match what people are actually using.

Change-Id: I6cfc72311db20b5feabbf282235132ae80bbecac

commit_message:
Separate remote log stream from local

This fix separates the remote log streams from the local
by binding the remote ruleset to the UDP and TCP input modules.
Additionally new overrides are provided to allow for better customization:
``rsyslog_server_logrotation_window`` defaults to 14 days
``rsyslog_server_ratelimit_interval`` defaults to 0 seconds
``rsyslog_server_ratelimit_burst`` defaults to 10000

The rsyslog.conf is also now using v7+ style configuration settings

Change-Id: I5759ea8fb7eaad79d857a335a4aede558aa0067d
Closes-Bug: #1621559
(cherry picked from commit 2e9a46068fce51c594f08d450d4432a417d29a99)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-rsyslog_server refs/changes/30/368030/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: rsyslog_server_logrotation_window: 14 #Number of days to keep logfiles # Rate limits rsyslog_server_ratelimit_interval: 0 # Disabled by default # To use this setting, you have to configure a interval >0 seconds for rsyslog_server_ratelimit_interval rsyslog_server_ratelimit_burst: 10000

commit_message:
Revert "Fix linuxbridge job breakage on xenial"

This reverts commit 209da22b603071cd48cd044e3e9efdbe10c02913.

This is the end of the chain to fix the eth0 issues on xenial.

Change-Id: I98b28d158dc5e9787342b354c065032453febe4a

commit_message:
Remove hardcoding to eth0 in LinuxBridge job configuration

The switch to xenial has revelead that hardcoding eth0 is
a bad idea and we should fall back to using the interface
for the default route [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/367699/

Depends-On: I7859437f97e6cab929e90208fe56f7efd62dfe01
Change-Id: Ib63268becee986a0a11e8ecbdb517b9d1e681583

commit_message:
Don't set up duplicate repos

This is required if seed and orig env repos has the same repos.
Set up only that repos that not found in orig env.

Change-Id: I6a953634e1482af1b89ab1f5da878f52152e7ada
Closes-bug: 1621491
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-octane refs/changes/94/367394/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PACKAGES_STR = " ".join(magic_consts.OSD_UPGRADE_REQUIRED_PACKAGES) class Repo(dict): SOURCE_KEY = "sources" def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(Repo, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self._cache = {} def invalidate_cache(self): self._cache = {} @property def source(self): if self.SOURCE_KEY in self._cache: return self._cache[self.SOURCE_KEY] self._cache[self.SOURCE_KEY] = apt.create_repo_source(self)[1] return self.source def get_preference(self, packages): return apt.create_repo_preferences(self, packages)[1] return '\n\n'.join([r.source for r in repos])def get_repos_for_upgrade(orig_env, seed_env): seed_repos = get_env_repos(seed_env) orig_repos_sources = {Repo(**r).source for r in get_env_repos(orig_env)} results = [] for repo in seed_repos: i_repo = Repo(**repo) if i_repo.source not in orig_repos_sources: results.append(i_repo) return results seed_repos = get_repos_for_upgrade(orig_env, seed_env)
deleted_lines: return '\n\n'.join([apt.create_repo_source(r)[1] for r in repos]) seed_repos = get_env_repos(seed_env)

octane/commands/cleanup.py

commit_message:
Removing gunicorn from requirements

Gunicorn is not part of global-requirements.
Having it here prevents check-requirements from working

Change-Id: I6575d42ad0566ec6727e0e359966e8129c003635

This is the second patch that implements the generic-volume-group
bluerpint. It adds the groups table and introduces create/delete/
update/list/show APIs for groups.

It depends on the first patch which adds group types and group specs:
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/320165/

Client side patch is here:
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/322627/

Current microversion is 3.8. The following CLI's are supported:

bluerpint. It adds the groups table and introduces create/delete/
update/list/show APIs for groups.

It depends on the first patch which adds group types and group specs:
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/320165/

Client side patch is here:
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/322627/

Current microversion is 3.11. The following CLI's are supported:
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.11 group-create --name my_group
    <group type uuid> <volume type uuid>
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.11 group-list
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.11 create --group-id <group uuid>
    --volume-type <volume type uuid> <size>
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.11 group-update <group uuid>
    --name new_name  description new_description
    --add-volumes <uuid of volume to add>
    --remove-volumes <uuid of volume to remove>
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.11 group-show <group uuid>
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.11 group-delete
    --delete-volumes <group uuid>

Change-Id: I35157439071786872bc9976741c4ef75698f7cb7
Partial-Implements: blueprint generic-volume-group

commit_message:
Add generic volume groups

This is the second patch that implements the generic-volume-group
bluerpint. It adds the groups table and introduces create/delete/
update/list/show APIs for groups.

It depends on the first patch which adds group types and group specs:
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/320165/

Client side patch is here:
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/322627/

Current microversion is 3.13. The following CLI's are supported:
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.13 group-create --name my_group
    <group type uuid> <volume type uuid>
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.13 group-list
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.13 create --group-id <group uuid>
    --volume-type <volume type uuid> <size>
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.13 group-update <group uuid>
    --name new_name  description new_description
    --add-volumes <uuid of volume to add>
    --remove-volumes <uuid of volume to remove>
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.13 group-show <group uuid>
cinder --os-volume-api-version 3.13 group-delete
    --delete-volumes <group uuid>

APIImpact
DocImpact
Change-Id: I35157439071786872bc9976741c4ef75698f7cb7
Partial-Implements: blueprint generic-volume-group
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/59/322459/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def create_group(self, context, group): """Creates a group.""" # A group entry is already created in db # This driver just returns a status now = timeutils.utcnow() model_update = {'status': fields.ConsistencyGroupStatus.AVAILABLE, 'updated_at': now} return model_update def delete_group(self, context, group, volumes): """Deletes a group and volumes in the group.""" model_update = {'status': group.status} volume_model_updates = [] for volume_ref in volumes: volume_model_update = {'id': volume_ref.id} try: self.remove_export(context, volume_ref) self.delete_volume(volume_ref) volume_model_update['status'] = 'deleted' except exception.VolumeIsBusy: volume_model_update['status'] = 'available' except Exception: volume_model_update['status'] = 'error' model_update['status'] = fields.ConsistencyGroupStatus.ERROR volume_model_updates.append(volume_model_update) return model_update, volume_model_updates # NOTE(xyang): The volume manager adds/removes the volume to/from the # group in the database. The LVM driver does not need to do anything. def update_group(self, context, group, add_volumes=None, remove_volumes=None): """Updates a group.""" return None, None, None

commit_message:
Use correct exception in L3 driver controller

The driver controller was using Invalid instead of InvalidInput
for validation errors. This was being converted to a 500 instead
of a BadRequest. This patch corrects it to use InvalidInput.

Change-Id: I8f4913fe8f98580a925d3f5b80ad0353e4c9636f
Partial-Bug: #1621430

commit_message:
Set sensible default for LB_PHYSICAL_INT

Configure the linux bridge physical interface to use the interface for
the default route on the current host. In the future we should consider
using a dangling interface so that we aren't affecting the host
instances networking but this roughly matches what testing has been
using in the past.

Change-Id: I7859437f97e6cab929e90208fe56f7efd62dfe01
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/99/367699/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default_route_dev=$(ip route | grep ^default | awk '{print $5}') die_if_not_set $LINENO default_route_dev "Failure retrieving default route device"LB_PHYSICAL_INTERFACE=${LB_PHYSICAL_INTERFACE:-$default_route_dev}
deleted_lines: LB_PHYSICAL_INTERFACE=${LB_PHYSICAL_INTERFACE:-}

subject: Change true to yes in default host labels
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-09 15:56:09.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/quickstart.rst', 'etc/kolla-kubernetes/kolla-kubernetes.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/376341bd0918cd7ed3aae1ef5c9af1b468972236', 'message': "Change true to yes in default host labels

The quotes are being stripped from the values and then true is being
cast to a bool that kube doesn't like. This changes the default to
'yes', which is a string

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I4248521e7fe648ac292cc5faafee9c659f6a5af0
"}]
commit_message:
Change true to yes in default host labels

The quotes are being stripped from the values and then true is being
cast to a bool that kube doesn't like. This changes the default to
'yes', which is a string

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I4248521e7fe648ac292cc5faafee9c659f6a5af0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes refs/changes/95/368095/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # value: 'yes'# value: 'yes' value: 'yes' value: 'yes'# value: 'yes'
deleted_lines: # value: 'true'# value: 'true' value: 'true' value: 'true'# value: 'true'

commit_message:
[config-ref] Update ceilometer sample configuration file

Change-Id: Ide91f9aa123474f531613914af2da2648369e48a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/41/365241/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # To reduce polling agent load, samples are sent to the notification agent in a # batch. To gain higher throughput at the cost of load set this to False. # (boolean value) #batch_polled_samples = true # To reduce large requests at same time to Nova or other components from # different compute agents, shuffle start time of polling task. (integer value)# Polling namespace(s) to be used while resource polling (list value) # Allowed values: compute, central, ipmi #polling_namespaces = compute,central # List of pollsters (or wildcard templates) to be used while polling (list # value) #pollster_list =# Inspector to use for inspecting the hypervisor layer. Known inspectors are # libvirt, hyperv, vmware, xenapi and powervm. (string value)# Override the default libvirt URI (which is dependent on libvirt_type). # (string value)# Dispatchers to process metering data. (multi valued) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/dispatcher #meter_dispatchers = database # Dispatchers to process event data. (multi valued) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/dispatcher #event_dispatchers = database# DEPRECATED: Allow novaclient's debug log output. (Use default_log_levels # instead) (boolean value) # This option is deprecated for removal. # Its value may be silently ignored in the future.# Refresh Pipeline configuration on-the-fly. (boolean value) #refresh_pipeline_cfg = false # Refresh Event Pipeline configuration on-the-fly. (boolean value) #refresh_event_pipeline_cfg = false # Polling interval for pipeline file configuration in seconds. (integer value) #pipeline_polling_interval = 20# Name of this node, which must be valid in an AMQP key. Can be an opaque # identifier. For ZeroMQ only, must be a valid host name, FQDN, or IP address. # (string value) #host = <your_hostname> # Timeout seconds for HTTP requests. Set it to None to disable timeout. # (integer value)# Indicates if expirer expires only samples. If set true, expired samples will # be deleted, but residual resource and meter definition data will remain. # (boolean value) #sql_expire_samples_only = false # Path to the rootwrap configuration file touse for running commands as root # (string value)# # From oslo.log # # If set to true, the logging level will be set to DEBUG instead of the default # INFO level. (boolean value) # Note: This option can be changed without restarting. #debug = false # DEPRECATED: If set to false, the logging level will be set to WARNING instead # of the default INFO level. (boolean value) # This option is deprecated for removal. # Its value may be silently ignored in the future. #verbose = true # The name of a logging configuration file. This file is appended to any # existing logging configuration files. For details about logging configuration # files, see the Python logging module documentation. Note that when logging # configuration files are used then all logging configuration is set in the # configuration file and other logging configuration options are ignored (for # example, logging_context_format_string). If MAC, token data is authenticated (with HMAC) in # the cache. If ENCRYPT, token data is encrypted and authenticated in # the cache. If the value is not one of these options or empty, # auth_token will raise an exception on initialization. (string value) #memcache_security_strategy = <None> # (Optional, mandatory if memcache_security_strategy is defined) This # string is used for key derivation. (string value)# (Optional) Number of seconds memcached server is considered dead # before it is tried again. (integer value)# (Optional) Maximum total number of open connections to every # memcached server. (integer value)# (Optional) Socket timeout in seconds for communicating with a # memcache server. (integer value)# (Optional) Number of seconds a connection to memcached is held # unused in the pool before it is closed. (integer value)# (Optional) Number of seconds that an operation will wait to get a # memcache client connection from the pool. (integer value)# (Optional) Use the advanced (eventlet safe) memcache client pool. # The advanced pool will only work under python 2.x. (boolean value)# (Optional) Indicate whether to set the X-Service-Catalog header. If # False, middleware will not ask for service catalog on token # validation and will not set the X-Service-Catalog header. (boolean # value)# Used to control the use and type of token binding. Can be set to: # "disabled" to not check token binding. "permissive" (default) to # validate binding information if the bind type is of a form known to # the server and ignore it if not. "strict" like "permissive" but if # the bind type is unknown the token will be rejected. "required" any # form of token binding is needed to be allowed. Finally the name of a # binding method that must be present in tokens. (string value)# If true, the revocation list will be checked for cached tokens. This # requires that PKI tokens are configured on the identity server. # (boolean value)# Hash algorithms to use for hashing PKI tokens. This may be a single # algorithm or multiple. The algorithms are those supported by Python # standard hashlib.new(). The hashes will be tried in the order given, # so put the preferred one first for performance. The result of the # first hash will be stored in the cache. This will typically be set # to multiple values only while migrating from a less secure algorithm # to a more secure one. Once all the old tokens are expired this # option should be set to a single value for better performance. (list # value)# Prefix to prepend at the beginning of the path. Deprecated, use # identity_uri. (string value) #auth_admin_prefix = # Host providing the admin Identity API endpoint. Deprecated, use # identity_uri. (string value) #auth_host = 127.0.0.1 # Port of the admin Identity API endpoint. Deprecated, use # identity_uri. (integer value) #auth_port = 35357 # Protocol of the admin Identity API endpoint (http or https). # Deprecated, use identity_uri. (string value) #auth_protocol = https # Complete admin Identity API endpoint. This should specify the # unversioned root endpoint e.g. https://localhost:35357/ (string # value) #identity_uri = <None> # This option is deprecated and may be removed in a future release. # Single shared secret with the Keystone configuration used for # bootstrapping a Keystone installation, or otherwise bypassing the # normal authentication process. This option should not be used, use # `admin_user` and `admin_password` instead. (string value) #admin_token = <None> # Service username. (string value) #admin_user = <None> # Service user password. (string value) #admin_password = <None> # Service tenant name. (string value) #admin_tenant_name = admin# Host to locate redis. (string value)# Use this port to connect to redis host. (integer value)# Password for Redis server (optional). (string value) #password = <None> [matchmaker_ring]# From oslo.messaging# Matchmaker ring file (JSON). (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/matchmaker_ringfile #ringfile = /etc/oslo/matchmaker_ring.json# WARNING: Ceilometer historically offered the ability to store events # as meters. This usage is NOT advised as it can flood the metering # database and cause performance degradation. This option disables the # collection of non-metric meters and will be the default behavior in # Liberty. (boolean value) #disable_non_metric_meters = false # Enable workload partitioning, allowing multiple notification agents # to be run simultaneously. (boolean value)# transport://user:pass@host1:port[,hostN:portN]/virtual_host # (DEFAULT/transport_url is used if empty) (multi valued)# Directory to use for lock files. For security, the specified # directory should only be writable by the user running the processes # that need locking. Defaults to environment variable OSLO_LOCK_PATH. # If external locks are used, a lock path must be set. (string value)# Name for the AMQP container (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [amqp1]/container_name #container_name = <None> # Timeout for inactive connections (in seconds) (integer value) # Deprecated group/name - [amqp1]/idle_timeout #idle_timeout = 0 # Debug: dump AMQP frames to stdout (boolean value) # Deprecated group/name - [amqp1]/trace #trace = false # CA certificate PEM file to verify server certificate (string # value) # Deprecated group/name - [amqp1]/ssl_ca_file #ssl_ca_file = # Identifying certificate PEM file to present to clients (string # value) # Deprecated group/name - [amqp1]/ssl_cert_file #ssl_cert_file = # Private key PEM file used to sign cert_file certificate (string # value) # Deprecated group/name - [amqp1]/ssl_key_file #ssl_key_file = # Password for decrypting ssl_key_file (if encrypted) (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [amqp1]/ssl_key_password #ssl_key_password = <None> # Accept clients using either SSL or plain TCP (boolean value) # Deprecated group/name - [amqp1]/allow_insecure_clients #allow_insecure_clients = false [oslo_messaging_qpid]# Use durable queues in AMQP. (boolean value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/rabbit_durable_queues #amqp_durable_queues = false # Auto-delete queues in AMQP. (boolean value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/amqp_auto_delete #amqp_auto_delete = false # Size of RPC connection pool. (integer value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/rpc_conn_pool_size #rpc_conn_pool_size = 30 # Qpid broker hostname. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_hostname #qpid_hostname = localhost # Qpid broker port. (integer value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_port #qpid_port = 5672 # Qpid HA cluster host:port pairs. (list value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_hosts #qpid_hosts = $qpid_hostname:$qpid_port # Username for Qpid connection. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_username #qpid_username = # Password for Qpid connection. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_password #qpid_password = # Space separated list of SASL mechanisms to use for auth. (string # value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_sasl_mechanisms #qpid_sasl_mechanisms = # Seconds between connection keepalive heartbeats. (integer value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_heartbeat #qpid_heartbeat = 60 # Transport to use, either 'tcp' or 'ssl'. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_protocol #qpid_protocol = tcp # Whether to disable the Nagle algorithm. (boolean value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_tcp_nodelay #qpid_tcp_nodelay = true # The number of prefetched messages held by receiver. (integer value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_receiver_capacity #qpid_receiver_capacity = 1 # The qpid topology version to use. Version 1 is what was originally # used by impl_qpid. Version 2 includes some backwards-incompatible # changes that allow broker federation to work. Users should update # to version 2 when they are able to take everything down, as it # requires a clean break. (integer value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/qpid_topology_version #qpid_topology_version = 1# Size of RPC connection pool. (integer value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/rpc_conn_pool_size #rpc_conn_pool_size = 30 # SSL version to use (valid only if SSL enabled). Valid values are # TLSv1 and SSLv23. SSLv2, SSLv3, TLSv1_1, and TLSv1_2 may be # available on some distributions. (string value)# SSL certification authority file (valid only if SSL enabled). # (string value)# How long to wait before reconnecting in response to an AMQP consumer # cancel notification. (floating point value)# The RabbitMQ broker address where a single node is used. (string# The RabbitMQ broker port where a single node is used. (integer# RabbitMQ HA cluster host:port pairs. (list value)# The RabbitMQ userid. (string value)# The RabbitMQ password. (string value)# The RabbitMQ virtual host. (string value)# How long to backoff for between retries when connecting to RabbitMQ. # (integer value)# Maximum number of RabbitMQ connection retries. Default is 0# Use HA queues in RabbitMQ (x-ha-policy: all). If you change this # option, you must wipe the RabbitMQ database. (boolean value)# Number of seconds after which the Rabbit broker is considered down # if heartbeat's keep-alive fails (0 disables the heartbeat, >0 # enables it. Enabling heartbeats requires kombu>=3.0.7 and # amqp>=1.4.0). EXPERIMENTAL (integer value) #heartbeat_timeout_threshold = 0# Deprecated, use rpc_backend=kombu+memory or rpc_backend=fake # (boolean value)# Default rule. Enforced when a requested rule is not found. (string # value)# Directories where policy configuration files are stored. They can be # relative to any directory in the search path defined by the # config_dir option, or absolute paths. The file defined by # policy_file must exist for these directories to be searched. # Missing or empty directories are ignored. (multi valued)# Work-load partitioning group prefix. Use only if you want to run # multiple polling agents with different config files. For each sub- # group of the agent pool with the same partitioning_group_prefix a # disjoint subset of pollsters should be loaded. (string value)# Secret value for signing messages. Set value empty if signing is not # required to avoid computational overhead. (string value)# The topic that ceilometer uses for metering notifications. (string # value)# The topic that ceilometer uses for event notifications. (string # value)# The driver that ceilometer uses for metering notifications. (string # value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/metering_driver[publisher_rpc] # # From ceilometer # # The topic that ceilometer uses for metering messages. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/metering_topic #metering_topic = metering # User name to use for OpenStack service access. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/os_username #os_username = ceilometer # Password to use for OpenStack service access. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/os_password #os_password = admin # Tenant ID to use for OpenStack service access. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/os_tenant_id #os_tenant_id = # Tenant name to use for OpenStack service access. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/os_tenant_name #os_tenant_name = admin # Certificate chain for SSL validation. (string value) #os_cacert = <None> # Auth URL to use for OpenStack service access. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/os_auth_url #os_auth_url = http://localhost:5000/v2.0 #os_region_name = <None> # Type of endpoint in Identity service catalog to use for # communication with OpenStack services. (string value) #os_endpoint_type = publicURL # Disables X.509 certificate validation when an SSL connection to # Identity Service is established. (boolean value) #insecure = false# IP address of the VMware Vsphere host. (string value)# Port of the VMware Vsphere host. (integer value)# Username of VMware Vsphere. (string value)# Password of VMware Vsphere. (string value)# Number of times a VMware Vsphere API may be retried. (integer value)# Sleep time in seconds for polling an ongoing async task. (floating # point value)# Optional vim service WSDL location e.g # http://<server>/vimService.wsdl. Optional over-ride to default # location for bug work-arounds. (string value)# Username for connection to XenServer/Xen Cloud Platform. (string # value)# Password for connection to XenServer/Xen Cloud Platform. (string # value) # Timeout in seconds for XenAPI login. (integer value) #login_timeout = 10

commit_message:
[config-ref] Update manila sample configuration file

Change-Id: I9d4fbaa58265815a49ac3f150cc946355927e2d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/40/365240/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #my_ip = <your_ip>#host = <your_hostname># The strategy to use for auth. Supports noauth, keystone, and # deprecated. (string value)# vNIC type used for binding. (string value) # Allowed values: baremetal, normal, direct, direct-physical, macvtap #neutron_vnic_type = baremetal # Host ID to be used when creating neutron port. If not set host is # set to manila-share host by default. (string value) #neutron_host_id = openstack-VirtualBox# Maximum Transmission Unit (MTU) value of the network. Default value # is 1500. (dict value) #protocol_access_mapping = ip:['nfs'],user:['cifs'] # String representation for an equation that will be used to filter # hosts. (string value) #goodness_function = <None> # Linux bridge used by container hypervisor to plug host-side veth to. # It will be unplugged from here by the driver. (string value) #container_linux_bridge_name = docker0 # OVS bridge to use to plug a container to. (string value) #container_ovs_bridge_name = br-int # Determines whether to allow guest access to CIFS share or not. # (boolean value) #container_cifs_guest_ok = true # Image to be used for a container-based share server. (string value) #container_image_name = manila-docker-container # Container helper which provides container-related operations to the # driver. This volume group must be # created by the cloud administrator independently from manila # operations. (string value) #container_volume_group = manila_docker_volumes # Allowed values: isilon, vnx, unity#emc_nas_server_container = <None> # EMC pool names. Enabling this might cause # inconsistent snapshots on CIFS shares. (boolean value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/hds_hnas_allow_cifs_snapshot_while_mounted #hitachi_hnas_allow_cifs_snapshot_while_mounted = false # HSP management host for communication between Manila controller and # HSP. (string value) #hitachi_hsp_host = <None> # HSP username to perform tasks such as create filesystems and shares. # (string value) #hitachi_hsp_username = <None> # HSP password for the username provided. (string value) #hitachi_hsp_password = <None># The File Provisioning Group (FPG) to use (FPG)#hpe3par_fpg = <None># NFS Server type. False:when Manila services are not running on any of the # Spectrum Scale node. Setting a # value of 0 indicates no limit. (integer value)#max_pool_size = 5# Minimum value: 0 # Maximum value: 100# Complete "public" Identity API endpoint. If you're using a versioned v2 # endpoint here, then this should *not* be the same endpoint the # service user utilizes for validating tokens, because normal end # users may not be able to reach that endpoint. commit_message:
Added Contrail Composable Services

commit_message:
Cleanup: Specs repos are branchless

Since specs repos are branchless and don't have stable branches, we do
not need to add ubuntu-trusty jobs that only run on stable branches.
Remove all of them from zuul and jenkins setup.

This removes around 90 jobs.

Change-Id: I478ae0ccfcb3d7811345ebafb5902bdefe4931c5

commit_message:
Fix links in devstack/README.rst

The github.com contains a mirror of the git.opoenstack.org but it should
not be treated as the official site to get openstack projects.

Change-Id: I31270f013f70ce250f0b48f20d2454ee5079c252
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/08/365808/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 1. Download DevStack:: $ git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack-dev/devstack $ cd devstack 2. Add the following repo as an external repository:: enable_plugin zaqar https://git.openstack.org/openstack/zaqar 3. Run ``./stack.sh``
deleted_lines: 1. Download DevStack 2. Add this repo as an external repository:: > cat local.conf enable_plugin zaqar https://github.com/openstack/zaqar 3. Run ``stack.sh``

For every # source aggregate associated with a cinder pool (NetApp FlexVol), you would # need to specify the destination aggregate on the replication target device. A # replication target device is configured with the configuration option # replication_device. Specify this option as many times as you have replication # devices. Each entry takes the standard dict config form: # netapp_replication_aggregate_map = # backend_id:<name_of_replication_device_section>,src_aggr_name1:dest_aggr_name1,src_aggr_name2:dest_aggr_name2,... # (dict value) #netapp_replication_aggregate_map = <None> # The maximum time in seconds to wait for existing SnapMirror transfers to # complete before aborting during a failover.
